short_definition: 2-AG (2-arachidonoylglycerol) is an endocannabinoid that activates both CB1 and CB2 receptors. It plays key roles in immune function and pain signaling.
Pre-filled CBD oil containers using the industry-standard 510 thread connection.
A skin condition causing pimples, typically from clogged hair follicles.
When a compound alters receptor function by binding at a secondary site rather than the main active site.
A progressive neurodegenerative disease affecting nerve cells controlling voluntary muscles.
A progressive brain disease causing memory loss and cognitive decline.
Anandamide is a naturally produced endocannabinoid often called the "bliss molecule." CBD may increase anandamide levels by inhibiting its breakdown.
Anti-inflammatory refers to substances that reduce inflammation. CBD has shown anti-inflammatory properties in studies by modulating immune responses.
A substance that prevents seizures; CBD is approved by regulatory agencies for certain epilepsy conditions.
Anxiety is a mental health condition characterized by persistent worry, fear, or unease that can interfere with daily life.
Anxiolytic means anxiety-reducing. CBD has shown anxiolytic properties in research, potentially helping manage anxiety through multiple mechanisms.
CBD may increase or decrease appetite depending on the individual and dose.
CBD may help arthritis symptoms through anti-inflammatory effects. Topical CBD products are popular for joint discomfort, though research is still ongoing.
A developmental condition affecting communication and behavior, with emerging CBD research.
Hemp varieties that flower automatically based on age rather than light exposure.
Batch numbers identify specific production runs of CBD products. They allow consumers to verify lab results and enable recalls if quality issues arise.
Batch testing verifies each production run of CBD products meets quality standards. Look for batch-specific COAs for the most accurate information.
Bioavailability measures how much CBD actually enters your bloodstream. It varies by method: sublingual (20-35%), oral (6-20%), inhaled (30-40%).
Raw hemp plant material used for CBD extraction.
When CBD produces different effects at low versus high doses.
A mental health condition causing extreme mood swings between depression and mania.
Bisabolol is a floral terpene found in hemp and chamomile. It may have anti-inflammatory and skin-healing properties, making it popular in CBD topicals.
CBD can increase blood thinner levels, raising bleeding risk—always consult your doctor.
Protective brain membrane that cannabinoids can cross due to their fat-soluble nature.
A dosing approach that calculates CBD amounts based on body weight.
A minty terpene that enhances compound absorption across the blood-brain barrier.
Broad-spectrum CBD includes multiple cannabinoids and terpenes but with THC fully removed. It offers entourage effect benefits without any THC content.
Creamy, butter-like cannabis concentrate retaining high terpene content.
An earthy, fir-scented terpene that may support cardiovascular health.
A non-psychoactive cannabinoid that may have anti-inflammatory and antidepressant properties.
A non-psychoactive cannabinoid from cannabis with potential therapeutic benefits including anxiety relief and anti-inflammatory effects.
The "mother cannabinoid" that serves as the precursor for other cannabinoids like CBD and THC.
The specific combination and concentration of cannabinoids in a product.
A mildly psychoactive cannabinoid formed from THC oxidation, known for potential sedative effects.
A cannabis variety traditionally associated with relaxing, sedating effects.
General term for oils from cannabis; can mean CBD oil, THC oil, or both.
A cannabis species traditionally associated with uplifting, energizing effects.
Carrier oils like MCT, hemp seed, or olive oil help deliver CBD and improve its absorption. They also allow for precise dosing in tincture products.
Beta-caryophyllene is a spicy terpene that uniquely binds to CB2 receptors. Found in hemp and black pepper, it may enhance anti-inflammatory effects.
CB1 receptors are found mainly in the brain and central nervous system. THC binds directly to CB1, while CBD has an indirect modulatory effect on them.
CB2 receptors are located primarily in immune cells and peripheral tissues. They play important roles in inflammation and immune response regulation.
CBD (cannabidiol) is a non-intoxicating compound from the cannabis plant, studied for potential therapeutic benefits including pain relief, anxiety reduction, and anti-inflammatory effects.
A thick, oil-based topical CBD product that creates a protective skin barrier.
Effervescent bath products that release CBD into bathwater for skin absorption.
Drinks infused with water-soluble CBD using nanoemulsion technology.
Oral CBD supplements in pill form providing precise, tasteless dosing.
Coffee products infused with CBD, potentially balancing caffeine's stimulating effects.
A water-based topical product for applying CBD directly to the skin.
Tool to estimate starting dose based on body weight and condition; adjust based on response.
CBD for feline anxiety and pain; cats metabolize differently, so use cat-specific products.
CBD may help dogs with anxiety, pain, and seizures; ensure products have minimal THC.
Edible CBD-infused candies offering convenient, pre-measured doses with longer-lasting effects.
CBD isolate is the purest form of cannabidiol available at 99%+ purity. All other cannabinoids, terpenes, and plant compounds are completely removed.
CBD cannot legally claim to cure or treat diseases; watch for 'miracle cure' red flags.
Adhesive patch delivering CBD through the skin over extended periods.
A soft, oil-based topical CBD product similar to balm but with softer consistency.
Liquid CBD extract taken under the tongue for fast absorption and precise dosing.
CBDA (cannabidiolic acid) is the raw, acidic form of CBD found in fresh hemp. It converts to CBD through heat in a process called decarboxylation.
CBDV (cannabidivarin) is a non-psychoactive cannabinoid similar to CBD. Early research suggests potential benefits for nausea and neurological conditions.
A minor cannabinoid formed when CBD degrades, typically found in aged cannabis products.
A Certificate of Analysis (COA) is an independent lab report showing cannabinoid content, potency, and contaminant testing results for CBD products.
Pharmaceutical manufacturing standards ensuring product quality and consistency.
Treatment-related nausea where cannabinoids are approved antiemetics in several countries.
A separation technique used to purify cannabinoids or remove unwanted compounds from hemp extract.
CBD may help manage chronic pain through anti-inflammatory effects and interaction with pain receptors. Many users report relief from ongoing pain.
Controlled research study testing treatments in human participants.
CO2 extraction uses pressurized carbon dioxide to pull CBD from hemp plants. It produces pure, solvent-free extracts and is the industry gold standard.
Pressing hemp seeds at low temperatures to extract oil—minimal processing.
Programs allowing access to unapproved treatments for seriously ill patients.
Presence of unwanted harmful substances in CBD products.
A condition or factor that makes CBD use inadvisable or risky.
Controlled substances are regulated by the DEA. While cannabis is Schedule I federally, hemp-derived CBD under 0.3% THC is not a controlled substance.
Rules governing the use of CBD in skincare and beauty products.
Inflammatory bowel disease where CBD may reduce intestinal inflammation.
The initial, unrefined extract from hemp containing all plant compounds.
Products not tested on animals; look for Leaping Bunny or PETA certification.
Dry, crumbly cannabis concentrate that's easy to handle and dose.
A cultivated variety of cannabis bred for specific desirable characteristics.
The controlled drying process that preserves cannabinoids and terpenes in harvested hemp.
Liver enzymes that metabolize CBD and many medications—the basis for drug interactions.
A method of consuming cannabis concentrates by vaporizing them on a heated surface.
Decarboxylation is the heat process that converts acidic CBDA to active CBD. Raw hemp contains acidic cannabinoids that must be heated to activate.
Delta-8 THC is a mildly psychoactive cannabinoid derived from hemp CBD. It offers a less intense experience than Delta-9 THC with legal ambiguity.
A metabolic disease affecting blood sugar regulation.
Single-use, pre-filled CBD vaping devices discarded after the oil is depleted.
A highly refined cannabis extract containing isolated cannabinoids, typically 85-95% pure THC or CBD.
CBD distillation is a purification process using heat and vacuum to isolate cannabinoids. It produces highly concentrated CBD oil, typically 80-90% pure.
A dose is the specific amount of a substance (like CBD) given at one time, measured in milligrams (mg).
Research where neither participants nor researchers know who receives treatment vs. placebo.
A rare, severe childhood epilepsy for which CBD (Epidiolex) is approved by regulatory agencies.
Sleepiness that can occur with CBD, especially at higher doses.
CBD drug interactions occur because CBD affects liver enzymes that metabolize many medications. Always consult a doctor before combining CBD with drugs.
A common CBD side effect where saliva production decreases temporarily.
How long CBD effects persist after they begin, varying by consumption method.
A chronic inflammatory skin condition causing itchy, red, dry patches.
Food or drink products infused with CBD for convenient, tasty consumption.
How well a treatment works under ideal, controlled conditions.
Theory that inadequate endocannabinoid levels may cause certain chronic conditions.
The endocannabinoid system (ECS) regulates balance in the body including mood, sleep, appetite, and pain response. CBD interacts with this system.
The baseline level of endocannabinoid system activity in the body.
A painful condition involving tissue growth outside the uterus; some use CBD for symptom management.
The entourage effect describes how cannabinoids and terpenes work together synergistically, potentially making full-spectrum CBD more effective overall.
The first approved by regulatory agencies CBD medication for treating severe forms of epilepsy.
Ethanol extraction uses food-grade alcohol to extract cannabinoids from hemp plants. It is efficient and can preserve the full spectrum of compounds.
European organic standard for hemp cultivation, indicated by the green leaf logo.
Highest European manufacturing standard for pharmaceutical-grade CBD products.
A cooling, minty terpene with respiratory benefits and cognitive support.
The enzyme that breaks down anandamide; CBD inhibits FAAH to increase anandamide levels.
Seeds bred to produce only female plants for maximum cannabinoid production.
Chronic pain condition where CBD may help through anti-inflammatory and sleep effects.
Liver processing that reduces CBD bioavailability when consumed orally.
Flavonoids are plant compounds found in cannabis that provide color and may offer anti-inflammatory and antioxidant benefits, working alongside cannabinoids in the entourage effect.
The smokable part of the cannabis plant containing the highest cannabinoid concentration.
The regulatory category determining how CBD products can be sold and marketed.
Full-spectrum CBD contains all hemp plant compounds including cannabinoids, terpenes, and trace THC under 0.3%. It benefits from the entourage effect.
A heat-based testing method less suitable for CBD products as it alters acidic cannabinoids.
A chronic condition of excessive worry; CBD shows promise as a treatment option.
Geraniol is a floral, rose-scented terpene found in hemp and geraniums. It may have neuroprotective and antioxidant properties when combined with CBD.
Eye condition causing nerve damage where THC may temporarily lower eye pressure.
Quality standards for pharmaceutical and supplement production ensuring consistency and safety.
An orphan receptor that responds to cannabinoids, sometimes called the third cannabinoid receptor.
If your medication warns against grapefruit, it likely interacts with CBD too.
CBD products compliant with Islamic law; must be THC-free and alcohol-free.
CBD half-life is the time for half the compound to leave your body, typically 18-32 hours. Factors include dosage, frequency of use, and metabolism rate.
Traditional concentrate made from compressed cannabis trichomes.
Lab analysis checking for toxic metals like lead, mercury, arsenic, and cadmium in CBD products.
Hemp is Cannabis sativa containing less than 0.3% THC. Federally legal under the 2018 Farm Bill, it is the source of most CBD products in the US.
A permit required for legal hemp cultivation, processing, or sales.
Hemp seed oil is pressed from hemp seeds and contains no CBD or THC cannabinoids. It is nutritious but different from CBD oil extracted from flowers.
Hemp and marijuana are both cannabis but differ legally by THC content. Hemp has under 0.3% THC and is legal; marijuana has more and is restricted.
A hydrogenated form of THC that produces similar but distinct psychoactive effects.
Homeostasis is the body's state of internal balance. The endocannabinoid system helps maintain homeostasis, and CBD may support this balancing function.
The standard laboratory method for accurately testing cannabinoid content in CBD products.
Humulene is an earthy, woody terpene in hemp and hops. It may have appetite-suppressing and anti-inflammatory properties combined with cannabinoids.
A genetic brain disorder causing progressive movement, cognitive, and psychiatric problems.
Hydrocarbon extraction uses butane or propane to extract cannabinoids from hemp. It requires careful purging to remove all solvent residue safely.
Water-repelling property of cannabinoids requiring special formulations for beverages.
A digestive disorder that may respond to cannabinoid treatment through gut receptors.
Rules governing international trade of hemp and CBD products.
Research conducted in test tubes or petri dishes outside of living organisms.
Research conducted in living organisms like animals or humans.
Non-CBD components like carrier oils and flavorings; check for allergens.
CBD inhalation through vaping provides the fastest onset of effects, typically within minutes. It offers high bioavailability but may affect lungs.
CBD may support sleep by addressing factors like anxiety and pain that disrupt rest. Some users combine CBD with CBN or melatonin for better sleep.
An international standard ensuring laboratory testing competence and reliability.
International quality standards; ISO 17025 for labs, ISO 9001 for manufacturers.
Fine powder of cannabis trichomes, more potent than flower.
CBD products certified to meet Jewish dietary laws under rabbinical supervision.
Document showing test results from independent laboratory analysis of CBD products.
Limonene is a citrus-scented terpene found in hemp and citrus fruits. It may promote elevated mood and provide stress relief when combined with CBD.
Linalool is a floral terpene found in hemp and lavender plants. Known for its calming properties, it may enhance the relaxing effects of CBD products.
Fat-soluble property of cannabinoids affecting absorption and storage in the body.
CBD encapsulated in tiny fat spheres (liposomes) for enhanced delivery and absorption.
Premium concentrate from flash-frozen cannabis preserving full terpene profile.
High CBD doses may elevate liver enzymes—important for those with liver conditions.
The ongoing CBD amount that provides consistent, sustained benefits.
Cannabis containing more than 0.3% THC, psychoactive and legally restricted.
MCT oil (medium-chain triglycerides) is a popular CBD carrier oil derived from coconut. It enhances absorption and provides quick energy to the body.
Statistical method combining results from multiple studies for stronger evidence.
To find CBD per mL: divide total mg by bottle mL. One dropper typically equals 1mL.
Testing for bacteria, mold, yeast, and other microorganisms in CBD products.
Taking very small amounts of CBD multiple times daily for subtle, consistent effects.
Severe headache disorder potentially linked to endocannabinoid deficiency.
The standard unit of measurement for CBD content and dosing.
The lowest CBD dose that produces desired therapeutic effects for an individual.
Cannabis compounds found in smaller concentrations than CBD or THC, including CBG, CBN, and CBC.
Autoimmune nerve disease where cannabis-based medications help manage spasticity.
Myrcene is an earthy, musky terpene that is abundant in hemp and hops. It may enhance CBD absorption and is associated with relaxing, sedative effects.
Ultra-small CBD particles with enhanced water solubility and faster absorption.
CBD delivered through nasal membranes for fast absorption without digestion.
A woody-floral terpene that enhances skin penetration for topical applications.
Nerve damage causing pain where cannabinoids show significant relief potential.
CBD shows neuroprotective potential in research studies, possibly supporting brain health through its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory mechanisms.
Chemical brain messengers regulated by the endocannabinoid system.
Product made without genetically modified organisms; most hemp is naturally non-GMO.
EU classification requiring authorization for foods not significantly consumed before 1997.
A complex condition involving excessive body fat that increases disease risk.
An anxiety disorder featuring unwanted repetitive thoughts and behaviors.
Ocimene is a sweet, herbaceous terpene found in hemp and various herbs. It may have antiviral and antifungal properties and adds to the entourage effect.
The time between CBD consumption and when effects become noticeable.
Oral CBD involves swallowing capsules, edibles, or oils. Effects take 30-90 minutes to onset but last longer than sublingual or inhaled methods of use.
Hemp grown without synthetic chemicals, following organic agricultural standards.
CBD products sold without prescription as supplements or cosmetics.
Pain is an unpleasant sensory experience associated with tissue damage or potential damage, which CBD may help manage.
A progressive nervous system disorder affecting movement and motor control.
Participants are the individuals who volunteer to take part in a research study, also called subjects or volunteers.
The maximum CBD level reached in the bloodstream after a dose.
Expert evaluation of scientific research before publication to ensure quality.
Convert percentage to mg by multiplying product weight by percentage.
Pesticide testing ensures CBD products are free from harmful agricultural chemicals. It is a critical safety check included in third-party lab analysis.
CBD may help pets with separation anxiety, noise phobia, and travel anxiety.
CBD shows promise for pet joint pain; Cornell study showed improvement in arthritic dogs.
CBD products formulated for animals with lower concentrations and pet-safe ingredients.
General starting point: 0.25-0.5mg CBD per kg body weight, twice daily.
Choose pet-specific formulas; avoid xylitol, chocolate, grapes, essential oils, and high THC.
Dogs, cats, and most mammals have endocannabinoid systems similar to humans.
CBD may reduce seizure frequency in epileptic dogs; research showed 89% reduction in some cases.
Cannabinoids produced naturally by the cannabis plant, as opposed to those made by the body or synthesized.
Pinene is a pine-scented terpene found in hemp and conifer trees. It may support alertness and respiratory function while complementing CBD's effects.
A placebo is an inactive treatment (like a sugar pill) used in clinical trials to compare against the actual treatment being tested.
Improvement experienced from belief in a treatment rather than the treatment itself.
Potency testing measures the concentration of cannabinoids in CBD products. It verifies that products contain the amount of CBD claimed on the label.
Nuclear receptors that regulate metabolism and inflammation, activated by some cannabinoids.
Ready-to-smoke hemp flower joints for convenient inhalation consumption.
Research phase before human trials including laboratory and animal studies.
Pharmaceutical-grade CBD requiring a doctor's prescription.
An autoimmune skin condition causing rapid skin cell buildup and scaly patches.
Psychoactive affects the mind (like caffeine); intoxicating impairs function (like alcohol).
Trauma-related disorder where cannabinoids may reduce anxiety and nightmares.
Scannable code linking to lab results for your specific batch; no QR code is a red flag.
CBD quality assurance includes testing, documentation, and manufacturing controls. Look for brands with transparent QA processes and third-party testing.
An RCT is a study where participants are randomly assigned to receive either the treatment being tested or a placebo/control, considered the gold standard for medical research.
The process of removing or reducing THC in hemp extracts to meet legal compliance.
Residual solvent testing ensures CBD extracts are free from extraction chemicals like butane, propane, and ethanol that may remain after processing.
A neurological condition causing leg discomfort; some patients report CBD provides relief.
Results are the findings and outcomes from a research study that show whether the treatment had an effect.
The backward communication method used by endocannabinoids in the nervous system.
An autoimmune disease causing chronic joint inflammation, pain, and potential joint damage.
Solventless concentrate made with heat and pressure, no chemicals required.
Highly concentrated full-spectrum cannabis extract, typically high in THC.
A serious mental disorder affecting thinking, emotions, and behavior.
Regulatory systems that track hemp products from cultivation through retail sale.
A serotonin receptor subtype directly activated by CBD, potentially explaining its anti-anxiety effects.
CBD serving size is the recommended amount per use, typically listed on product labels. It helps consumers calculate their total daily CBD intake.
Glass-like, highly pure cannabis concentrate that shatters when broken.
How long a CBD product remains effective, typically 1-2 years if stored properly.
A vacuum distillation technique for creating highly concentrated cannabinoid distillates.
Unwanted effects that may occur when using CBD, typically mild.
Sleep is a natural state of rest essential for health. CBD has been studied for potential benefits in improving sleep quality and duration.
Soft gelatin capsules containing liquid CBD oil for potentially better absorption.
Extraction methods using only heat, pressure, or water—no chemical solvents.
The recommended initial CBD amount for new users, typically 5-20mg daily.
A specific variety of cannabis with distinct characteristics, being replaced by 'cultivar'.
Sublingual CBD administration involves holding oil under the tongue for 60-90 seconds. This delivery method provides faster absorption than swallowing.
A condition involving compulsive substance use despite harmful consequences.
Using CO₂ at supercritical state (liquid-gas hybrid) for precise cannabinoid extraction.
CBD suppositories deliver cannabidiol rectally or vaginally for direct absorption. They bypass first-pass metabolism for faster, stronger effects.
Symptoms are physical or mental signs of a condition that participants experience, which researchers measure to assess treatment effects.
Comprehensive analysis of all available research on a topic using rigorous methodology.
The specific combination and concentration of terpenes in a cannabis product.
Terpinolene is a floral, piney terpene found in hemp and tea tree. It may have sedative and antioxidant properties and contributes to the entourage effect.
The primary psychoactive compound in cannabis that produces the "high" sensation by binding to CB1 receptors.
Products with non-detectable THC levels, important for drug testing and zero-tolerance countries.
A synthetic, acetylated form of THC reported to be more potent than natural THC.
THCA (tetrahydrocannabinolic acid) is the non-psychoactive THC precursor found in raw cannabis. It converts to psychoactive THC when heated or aged.
THCV (tetrahydrocannabivarin) is a cannabinoid that may suppress appetite and provide energizing effects. It has a shorter duration than regular THC.
The dose range where CBD provides benefits without significant side effects.
Third-party testing by independent labs verifies CBD product contents and purity. Always check for a current Certificate of Analysis before purchasing.
Titration is the process of gradually adjusting your CBD dosage to find the optimal amount. Start low and increase slowly while monitoring the effects.
Reduced response to CBD over time, requiring higher doses for the same effect.
CBD topicals are creams, balms, and lotions applied directly to skin for localized relief. They provide targeted benefits without entering bloodstream.
A neurological disorder characterized by repetitive, involuntary movements and vocalizations (tics).
CBD patches or gels that penetrate skin to enter the bloodstream for sustained release.
Treatment refers to the intervention being studied, such as CBD administration, to manage or improve a health condition.
Tiny crystal-like glands on cannabis that produce cannabinoids and terpenes.
An ion channel receptor that responds to heat, capsaicin, and cannabinoids, involved in pain perception.
A sweet citrus terpene with anti-inflammatory and skin-protective properties.
Heating CBD to release vapor without combustion, considered safer than smoking.
CBD products without animal-derived ingredients; check for gelatin, beeswax, or lanolin.
Emerging field studying cannabinoids for animal health, limited by legal restrictions.
Water-soluble CBD uses nanoemulsion technology for improved bioavailability. It mixes easily with beverages and absorbs faster than oil-based CBD products.
Soft, opaque cannabis concentrate with a waxy texture for dabbing.
A purification process using cold temperatures to remove fats and waxes from CBD extract.
